quoteLast: in the Moon’s Path; and at _u_, 34 minutes past 10 in the Path of _London_. Then, upon the Point _u_ as a center, describe the Circle _zYy_ whose Radius _uy_ is equal to the Sun’s semi-diameter 16ʹ 6ʺ § 367, taken from the Scale _CA_: And upon the Point _t_ as a center, describe the Circle _Hy_ whose Radius is equal to the Moon’s semi-diameter 14ʹ 58ʺ § 367, taken from the same Scale.
title:
Astronomy Explained Upon Sir Isaac Newton's Principles
And made easy to those who have not studied mathematics
author: Ferguson, James, 1710-1776

quoteFirst: Apply one side of a Square to the Line of the Moon’s Path, and move the Square backward or forward until the other side cuts the same hour and minute both in the Path of the Place (_London_, in this Construction) and Path of the Moon; and _that_ minute, cut at the same time in both Paths, will be the precise minute of visible Conjunction of the Sun and Moon at _London_, and therefore the time of greatest obscuration, or middle of the Eclipse at _London_; which time, in this Projection, falls at _t_,
quoteLast: in the Moon’s Path; and at _u_, 34 minutes past 10 in the Path of _London_. Then, upon the Point _u_ as a center, describe the Circle _zYy_ whose Radius _uy_ is equal to the Sun’s semi-diameter 16ʹ 6ʺ § 367, taken from the Scale _CA_: And upon the Point _t_ as a center, describe the Circle _Hy_ whose Radius is equal to the Moon’s semi-diameter 14ʹ 58ʺ § 367, taken from the same Scale.
title:
Astronomy Explained Upon Sir Isaac Newton's Principles
And made easy to those who have not studied mathematics
author: Ferguson, James, 1710-1776
